Browsing the menu and debating whether to order something. A customer walked in and  volunteered how good everything was. Well then....

Can only speak to the marinated BBQ chicken (#29 Gai Yang). Served with a spicy sweet and sour sauce. Big enough to fill a burrito one day and a sandwich the next.

Yours for an extremely reasonable $10 with tax.

It wasn't just good. It was great.

Consider it a heads up.
author: Jason B.

description: Green curry is good but does not include rice FYI.  The pad thai was disappointing zero spiciness and a flavor similar to ketchup? Good service.
author: Trent K.

description: I recently enjoyed some great meals at Lemongrass Thai while visiting your beautiful city! Consistency is a hallmark of a great restaurant, and each meal was a fresh and appetizing combination of flavors, served promptly. I really loved the Meung-kum?, an appetizing, flavor laden spinach leaf wrap containing roasted peanuts in a savory sauce, ginger, toasted coconut and freshly cut lemon, which also had an appealing crunchiness along with it's tasty ingredients, a real knockout! Crunchy rice and the savory lemongrass chicken, are both incredibly delicious!
author: Fred B.

description:
Small, intimate restaurant that can get crowded and loud at times. 

I really like their curries which have good flavor while retaining the nice underlying coconut milk taste and the tom yum noodle soup is quite good too. 

I'm not such a fan of the Pad Thai which had a strangely flavored sauce but I'm looking forward to trying other things on their menu. 

Price seems to be about average, at +/- $15 pp with tax and tip for an entree and rice

Lemongrass is a solid Thai option in the Nob Hill area, though maybe not spectacular enough to get a 5th star.
author: Russ C.

description: Sorry, it's just bad food.  Have been a few times over years.  Tonight final try.  With a dozen people in my party we ordered many dishes.  There was not one that I'll remember.  Taste just doesn't do a service to Thai cuisine.  The pad thai noodles clumped, the sauces were watery, quality of chicken poor.  Service was fine.  Packed in tables made me feel like I was on an airplane.  Aux delices across the street much better bet and consistently good as this place has been consistently bad.  Entire table agrees with this review.
author: C R.

description:
The food is pretty good but the service is consistently awful. We waited 15 minutes without water before she took our order. We requested water and it was another 10 minutes before we got it. Our appetizer took an additional 10 minutes and then 20 minutes after we were done with that our main dishes came out. 

I've been here several times and they always are seemingly understaffed. I would say they could stand to hire at least two more waitresses and maybe some more cooks.

Not worth coming here considering all the other decent Thai restaurants on Polk.
author: K C.

description: I really wanted to like Lemongrass so I went twice and got different things both times - the Tom Kha Gai and the Pineapple Fried Rice. The soup was pretty lackluster and the pineapple fried rice was straight up bland. I was getting sick both times I went so maybe it's my palate but I always get Thai when I'm sick so if I can't enjoy your cuisine with a little virus then it kind of defeats the spicy, comforting purpose.
author: Claire H.

description:
Lemongrass is our go-to for Thai delivery.  I love that they will deliver to north beach.  

Some faves are: red chicken curry extra spicy, pad pak raummit (sauteed mixed vegetables in oyster sauce), chicken satay, and the tom kha soup.

One of the things that really sets them apart for me is their amazingly easy online ordering system.  I don't know why I hate calling in to-go orders, but I do.
author: Meagan C.

description: Let me start by saying that this review is after ordering from here via Eat24. I ordered on a Friday night a little after 7pm and was given a 50 minute delivery estimate. After waiting for more than an hour I called the restaurant to see if they had sent a driver. Someone picked up the phone but didn't ever say anything. I waited thinking maybe I missed them asking me to hold, but after listening to the noise in the restaurant for a few minutes I hung up. From there I reached out to Eat24 and after some waiting was told he'd be there in 10 minutes. 15 minutes pass and I ask again. There wasn't a quick answer and now that we'd been waiting almost an hour we finally get a call from the driver. He said he had already stopped by once but no one had called either from the front door to be buzzed in or called my phone directly. He said he then left made another delivery and then would be at my building in 5 minutes and could I meet him out front. I did go out to pick up that food, but after waiting almost 2 hours I was definitely hangry, picking up food that was now cold and only received a $5 discount. We ordered the Pad Thai spicy which cold as one big lump of noodles is not great and there wasn't much spice to it either. We also ordered the Gai Kraprow with chicken, but there wasn't much chicken - mostly onions & bamboo shoots. Also cold when delivered.
author: Joy A.

description: For my first stop in San Fran I wanted to get the best thai I could find. Thhhhis wasn't quite what I was hoping for. When I asked if something on the menu was warm and savory, my server said yes but when she brought my food out it was a sweet dish with raw spinach and other cold toppings. I tried to enjoy it for what it was but when I ate my first but I knew I couldn't eat it for whatever reasons my taste buds have. She took it back and brought me something else but they still made me pay for both, without apology. I ain't mad...just unsatisfied yo!
author: Taylor R.

description: Had a light late lunch one day of a chicken salad item.  Total cost was $10.  It was ok, though I would have liked it on a bigger plate or in a bowl since it was hard to maneuver the lettuce without it spilling off.  Nice lemongrass and fresh vegetables, though it did not over impress me.  I would return to give some other items on the menu a try.  Nice calm place when all the other places on Polk are packed on a weekend.
author: Marc S.

description:
I really enjoy Lemongrass Thai! Here are some reasons:

1) we ordered delivery the other night and it arrived in about 20 minutes
2) you can actually order your delivery through an online form
3) the portions are huge and the food is really good
4) the sauces are particularly good like the dipping sauce for the fresh spring rolls
5) the servers are very friendly when I've eaten there
6) the prices are reasonable

And... I better stop because it's late at night and my mouth is watering!
author: Meghan P.

description: No winners here-- I've never met the chef but I get the impression he doesn't like me.
author: Colin B.

description:
I wouldn't call Lemongrass a "destination" kind of restaurant; it is most definitely a neighborhood spot for folks that live within walking distance (like yours truly).  

Service is fine, ambiance is fair... you might want to consider take-out instead.  The food is good: reasonably priced, good portions, and noodles that taste fresh (not "gummy").  Limited selection of beer and wine.  

Lemongrass is A-okay in my book.
author: Julie H.

description:
I brought my husband, niece and her two friends to Lemongrass for yet another superb experience.  As a native San Franciscan and regular patron of this Russian Hill restaurant, Lemongrass is warm, cozy and just as elegant as it has ever been.

Toi, the owner, and lead chef is a most gracious hostess.  We are always made to feel welcome and therefore bring our friends, family and even clients here for lunch and dinner.  I still adore green curry...the vegetable dishes, appetizers and especially the dessert of fried banana with honey...all delicious.

My family, friends and I wish Toi and her family owned restaurant continued success for many years to come...thank you for the great food and service!
author: Alacrity I.

description:
if you're a fan of green curry, this is your place!

4 stars bc I'm not a big fan of their other dishes
author: Sumeet S.

description:
Good taste, yet I can't shrug off the feeling being taken for a ride if a seafood combo comes with veggies and 9 pieces of shrimp (after we asked for more seafood.... increasing the # of "seafood"(shrimp only) from 5 to 9....
So, we will not be back. Sorry.
author: To K.

description:
Lemongrass is the best Thai restaurant in the city.  I have lived in San Francisco for over 20 years and love Thai food. So, I have tried a lot of Thai restaurants in SF. I have taken friends and relatives there who loved it. 
In addition to the food and preparation, the atmosphere is beautiful. 
I have also done take-out and it is excellent.
author: Christy D.

description:
Maybe it's 'cause we're from the Seattle-area and we're used to terrific Thai food (even in our suburban neighborhood and even as far north as Mt. Vernon).  REAL Thai food, not Chinese-like Thai food.  Daughter, from Japan, however, agreed that this restaurant was sub-par.

We had been recommended this restaurant by a Fisherman's Wharf-hotel concierge with 35 years experience.  We were happy with the decor and the waitresses's outfits, both which looked relatively authentic.  So we were optimistic.  We should have, however, been afraid when we asked for 1 star on one of the dishes and the waitress looked really puzzled and said that they don't serve the food spicy.

We started out with the Appetizer Combination.  This was pretty good, actually.  And nicely presented.  However, it was more for two, not for three or more.

We then shared some Tom Kha chicken.  Not bad.  But almost raw mushrooms.  And no other vegetables.  Just chicken and mushrooms.

Then, our main dishes.  Phad Thai with absolutely no veggies whatsoever!  And no spiciness, which is how daughter had ordered it.  But the Phad See Ew beef was absolutely not spicy even though we'd asked for 2 stars.  Hubby needed hot sauce.  It wasn't bad, but just wasn't up to the level of phad see ew in the Seattle area.  My beef with vegetables dish was not only super salty (or, I suspect, had MSG), but the large amount of Chinese greens in it (which I'd never seen ever before in Thai dishes) were uncut and, even after chewing on it for awhile, almost choked on it.  In any case, this was definitely NOT Thai food; it was Chinese food attempting to be Thai.  (While not so bad as the Almond Fried Chicken days of Spokane, in comparison, it seemed so.)

To top it all off, the service was also rather lackluster.  No one advised my dish did not come with rice (which I don't even believe was Jasmine) nor suggest that it be ordered. Nor did the waitress ask what type meat for the phad Thai.  And, besides, we waited for what seemed to be an eternity to order.

The saving grace was the fried banana with ice cream.  While it couldn't compare to Mt. Vernon's Thai House, it was still tasty.  Lots of ice cream, which I like.  And a big enough portion to feed 3.

I can only assume that the cuisine has gone downhill since voted Best in the Bay in 2010.

Bottom line: unless you're only wanting dessert, try some other restaurant (assuming a good one exists).
author: C B.

description:
Pineapple fried rice= Amazing!

Rice noodles where awsome! Fresh ingredients.

I got a dish that I forget the name of but it was basically chicken seasoned with basil and other herbs. Flavor was good but the chicken was dry :(

But def comming back again when Im in San Francisco!
author: Fabiola R.

description:
ABSOLUTELY AMAZING THAI FOOD!!   We decided to randomly try Lemongrass the other night as an alternative to Osha and we where blown away by the food!   It's quick, very fresh, simple flavors and surprisingly inexpensive!

We are completely sold on the place and already talking about the next time we will be going there.

Kudos to the owner, chef and team there!
author: A R.

description:
Really great delivery. Delicious authentic thai. Usually arrives in under 30 minutes. Some of my personal favorites:
   Crispy rice salad
   Silver noodle soup
   Pad See Ew 
   Satay
Just to name a few.
author: Chelsea C.

description:
I went there primarily because of 3.5 stars on yelp and some of the positive reviews.  I love Thai food and eaten at some of the best Thai restaurants in the country.  And this was no 3.5 star quality restaurant and I would rate the food quality to be ordinary at the best.  I would give it 3.5 stars....but out of 10.

On the positive side, the ambience was good and prices seemed very reasonable.  For folks who are starting out on Thai cuisine...this would seem okay.  But for the real Thai food aficionado's...there are better places in San Francisco
author: Sandman D.

description: This was our first time dining here and our expectations were met. The staff was friendly, attentive, and the food was great. We ordered the green curry with salmon and sweet and sour pork- we especially loved the green curry.  Price was reasonable and we will definitely be back!
author: James L.

description: The meal we had was a good and solid 3.0 based on the tom yum soup, pad spinach, red curry prawns, and the beef pad see-ew noodles. The service was great and friendly. Overall, a meal that you can't go wrong in a nice neighborhood.
author: Derek N.

description: With most Thai restaurants, I'm skeptical of fish curries -- they're typically overcooked, but Lemongrass Thai recommended their salmon green curry, so I tried it:  the salmon was awesome.  Really tasty, not overcooked at all.  I'd definitely get it again.
author: Mike V.

description:
I love Thai food, and definitely have had better. ( maybe cos I actually have lived in Thailand before, and know what Authentic Thai should taste like )

The staff here is soooo nice.
But the food wasn't just soooo great.
Everything is super greasy. Their Tom Yum soup had fake mushrooms in it. ( OK they are not fake but just the gross canned ones ) 
Their pad thai tasted like something else, just not pad thai. Oye - was oober disappointed.

BUT if u are just right around at Green's sportsbar, and wants some greasy take-out while watching the games... this will be your good option.
author: ThuZ W.

description: They delivered quickly to my hotel. That was very nice but delivery man has no change for a 20!! Food was lack luster at best. They are not using the proper ingredients. I would not try them ever again.
author: Kim K.

description:
First time visiting Russian hill's little Thai restaurant lemongrass. Have to admit the yogurt/rice pudding place next door drew us across the street. Upon sitting down in the quaint window seats for two we ordered egg rolls, number 62 noodle soup an yellow chicken curry. 

The egg rolls were dynamite. A definite must have nomnom give me more..

Next the 62 seafood soup was very satisfying and delish. The hint of lime added just enough acid to cut the chicken broth. As a previous reviewer mentioned great for hang overs

Lastly the chicken curry was good but not amazing, cooked a little bit long and potatoes need a little more home made  loving.

Overall a good night out, a place to come back to.... For the egg rolls
author: Danny M.

description: Wandered in here hungry for lunch today and we ordered pad Thai with shrimp and chicken satay. Both were not tasty at all. I am a lover of pad Thai and frequent traveler to Thailand and this was one of the worst I've ever had. It tasted like noodles doused in pure sweet and sour sauce. The satay had clearly just been reheated as it was still cold in the center. Other than that it's a nice place with a lot of seating....maybe other food options are better, but I don't think I'll be back to find out.
author: Allie M.

description: When we come to San Fran and have a craving for yellow curry, we come here!
author: Virginia M.

description: The Yelp reviews really mislead me. I'm from NY so maybe my standards for good thai food are a little higher, but this was not good food. We ordered chicken pad thai and pad see eew (which are usually not hard to mess up); however, the food lacked in flavor, texture, and did not even taste like thai food. It was horrendous.
author: Aed L.

description:
I walked in and I thought I was no longer in San Francisco. Definitely a place that stands out against the crowds of restaurants in the neighborhood. 

Food was great and appetizing. Ordered the following:
BBQ chicken
Yellow curry chicken
Chicken satay
And my favorite fried banana with vanilla ice cream

Our server was nice to always check in on us. Overall the service was great!

This is my favorite Thai restaurant in San Francisco. Parking could be hard but worth the try!
author: J C.

description: Can't go wrong with Pad Thai and Pineapple Fried Rice. I didn't think the pad see ew was very good (but can see if you like spicey food, you might like it). Friendly staff :)
author: Katherine L.

description:
I Loved it this place!!
The service is very good and fast, the food is delicious, the atmosphere is casual and great value for the price!  
I will definitely come back !!
author: Ornella G.

description:
Lemongrass know Thai!

This is good Thai food.  They don't ask what level of spiciness.  The dishes are prepared how they mean and the service is quick!  Definitely worth a walk uphill.
author: Don G.

description:
Relatively inexpensive, cute thai place with friendly staff. 
Voted Best in the Bay 2010.

Yellow curry is a tad more spicy than most yellow curry I have had, but still good. (Has onions and potatoes in it)

The Lemongrass Chicken on the specials menu was good - think a mix between peanuts and bell peppers - but next time I will probably go for noodles.

I will definitely go back because it is so close to the apartment and decently priced, decently tasting.

However, only tasting the Pad Thai will tell...
author: Allie E.

description: I am a little sad and reluctant to write this update but it must be said: the quality has noticeably decreased at lemongrass. My go to lemongrass special noodle has been lacking, my backup eggplant and tofu dish was awful the last time I ordered it, and the service has not been as helpful as it was in the past. Sad :(
author: Sarah Z.

description:
After walking around the hills in the neighborhood down to the fisherman's wharf and on to the Haight and then to tour the USF campus for a couple hours, you can bet that the hubby and I were pretty tired. So tired, in fact, that we couldn't bear walking even another block to pick up dinner. Thanks to Yelpers, and Lemongrass Thai, we didn't have to!

They delivered right to our hotel. The same lady who answered the phone when I ordered delivered the food. She may have been the owner. She was super sweet. She predicted it might take 30 minutes for the food to get there, but it made it, piping hot, in under 15. 

For an appetizer, we ordered the veggie egg rolls -- and these were not your ordinary veggie eggrolls! They were crispy and delicious, and more than enough for two. And the sauce -- sweet and a little spicy, and just perfect. 


For dinner my husband had the pad thai with chicken, and I had the pad keemaw with shrimp. Both were excellent. Mine had a ton of shrimp, and was pretty spicy but in a good way. If you have issues with cilantro at all though, I would steer clear of this dish. Mine had quite a bit. 

The Verdict: If we lived in the neighborhood, the delivery here would definitely be deliciously dangerous.
author: Cara S.

description:
This place was a surprisingly good find considering I walked in without consulting any Yelp reviews (I'm always so apprehensive when I do that!). The food was decently priced which was what drew me in in the first place, and the ambiance inside was very nice as well. Also, the menu had a great selection of Thai classics as well as lesser known dishes. 

I ordered the sauteed fish and it was very good - highly recommended! Often I get sick of just pad thai and pad see ew but I like the noodles so I ordered some on the side to go with my fish. I was hoping they would at least sautee the noodles but it was just boiled plain...I managed though by smothering it with my fish sautee sauce and mixing it myself on the plate. Not the classiest of moves but hey - it was good! 

A week later I tried ordering their takeout since it was such a cold cold rainy San Francisco day. The food was steaming hot when I got it, they said 45 minutes - it was there in 35 minutes! All in all a good experience. The food itself was not that wonderful but I blame it more on more ordering than their cooking. 

This is a good place for dinner after work on a normal night when you are just too tired to cook, don't feel like splurging yet could use some yum in your tum. I will definitely be back for some more feel good freshly cooked thai!

3.5 stars...leaning towards the 4
author: Christina L.

description: Try the Panang curry with chicken instead of beef. SO GOOD.
author: KC W.

description: I'm really sad to downgrade this place to 2 stars, but I was completely disappointed today.  Lemongrass has always had a few dishes that I absolutely obsessed about, and I rarely go there anymore because I live in the East Bay.  Today I had some time to kill and went for lunch.   I always order, and have obsessed about, the crispy rice salad.  Today, what historically has been a killer salad, fell short for me.  It still had crazy good flavors, but was swimming in it's own juices and didn't do it for me today.  The other dish I obsessed about was a spicy tofu and green bean dish that I guess isn't on the menu anymore, but the chef used to make it special for me.  No such luck today.  In fact, the staff used to bend over backwards to be accommodating and attentive...not today.  I ordered some pad thai (my friend ALWAYS orders it and is wow'ed by it)...I must say, it was the worst pad thai ever.  No lime, no peanut, scant cabbage, no cilantro, no recognizable egg, barely any tofu and barely any flavor.  As one reviewer put, it definitely seemed like some corners are being cut to save on costs.  Sorry Lemongrass...doubt I'll be back.  There are many many Thai restaurants out there.  You've just lost a loyal customer.
author: Jean K.

description: I went there for lunch today. I rate 3 stars because the pad Thai was good the waitress nice, but it was so cold inside I had to keep my coat on. Plus someone was painting the front door at 12.30 with the door most likely open, so you get the awful smell while you eat plus more cold. It bugged me that they would paint something at this time of the day when people are actually coming to eat !!!! Wtf ??
author: Marion P.

description:
Lemongrass Thai in San Francisco is the best Thai food you can get in the Bay Area.  I have been a regular at this establishment for 8 years.  I love all the wonderful flavors that "dazzle" your mouth during the course of a meal here.  The owner, Toi Sawatdee, welcomes you personally, when she is not out shopping for the day's food, or cooking in her small kitchen.   Each dish is cooked to your liking, including spicy or not.   

Another convenient feature of Lemongrass is their free delivery, which makes life easier, for those of us "on the go."  My personal favorites are crispy rice salad, mieng-kum, green curry and the tom yum pak soup, for its fresh flavors.  I highly recommend Lemongrass Thai, on Polk St., near Union.  You can't go wrong and the prices are reasonable.
author: Karen S.

description:
Amazing service and just okay Thai food. 

This is a good place to come for a cheap dinner (if you don't get alcohol, probably not going to happen *nudge nudge). The waitresses were really friendly and the food came out timed nicely. I liked the Appetizer Combo the best which came with egg rolls, Thai sticks and chicken satay. Its a nice way to try a lot of different things. 

The Tom Kha Gai coconut soup was good. The serving was huge. I barely had half. I thought that everything was a little greasy for my liking, and I left feeling so full. We ordered way too much food. Next time I will try a curry.
author: Natalie N.

description:
My regular Thai delivery went out of business, so I went [where else] to Yelp which lead me to Lemongrass Thai. 

I was preparing for a large business meeting and the owner/chef, Toi, answered the phone. She helped me create a wonderful menu, and seemed very genuinely appreciative of my business.

They arrived right on time (huge points). The food was AMAAAZING. Our clients from Sweden raved. They hardly spoke over lunch (good sign). Their plates were cleaned. 

I tried each dish myself, and wow... I'm not sure that what I've had in the past called Thai was actually Thai - this is THAI. Okay, the deets, the dishes that were clear winners:

-Beef w/ Garlic & Black Pepper (tangy, garlic'y beef, mmmm!)
-Mint Noodles w/ Vegetables (wide noodles w/ subtle mint, crisp veggies)
-Veggie Egg Roll (best I've ever had, pretty large, very crispy even though they were delivered and sat for a few before we broke for lunch)

Great value for the price, dependable, DELICIOUS.
author: S S.

description: We try to get to San Francisco at least once a year to escape the Phoenix heat.  When we go, we MUST hit Lemongrass.  Love the neighborhood, the atmosphere and the food.  We've enjoyed everything we've had.  We always get the pad thai and a second dish.  Very good food - very good prices.  Can't wait to get back there.
author: Alicia B.

description: Pleasant people, pleasant decor.  Service a little too attentive if anything - kept having to fight off having our water topped up every 30 seconds in the drought and my wine glass was whisked away with a sip still left.  Papaya salad was not bad.  "Three Delights" was dull but adequate.  Gai Yang - marinated barbecued chicken - should be moist and bursting with flavor.  This was dry and tasteless and about half of it was stone cold - obviously the result of uneven micrwaving.
author: David W.

description: Today the service was pretty bad. The food was good (prawn green curry, chicken yellow curry, pad thai and thai stick) but waitresses were unfriendly, forgot the rice and where annoyed when we asked for a knife.
author: Chris S.

description: Get the pineapple fried rice, it's delicious. I've had dinner here, both dine in and take out, a few times and I always leave satisfied. The wait staff is friendly, the food is cooked fresh, but pretty quickly, and the prices are reasonable. The ambiance is not distracting and feels cozy. Try it out!
author: Melissa A.

description: Great food, ambiance, red curry was delish, pineapple fried rice very good. Service a bit slow but the ladies were lovely. They also were kind enuff to allow a quirky substitution.
author: Roger D.

description:
I eat here probably twice a week. It's two blocks from my apartment, but I'd eat here just as often if I lived a mile away. The food here is exceedingly fresh, flavorful and touches every bit of the palate. My favorite dishes are the Gai Kraprow (sauteed basil chicken with peppers, onions, bamboo soots and a side of rice), and the Silver Noodles Yum Jay (a warm vegetarian salad with fresh veggies, rice noodles, tofu, onions and a light dressing). Today I tried their Chicken Tom Yum, a fantastic rice noodle soup that just explodes with flavor. There really isn't anything you can't get at Lemongrass; their menu is enormous. 

The prices here are absurdly low considering the high quality of the dishes.
author: Andrew K.

description:
Oh how I miss Toi and her incredible Thai food! I ate here more than any other restaurant when I lived in the city. Everything is delicious, but I always order the Seafood Green Curry when I'm up from the Peninsula. And now my children love it as much as I do!
Great prices in a great looking restaurant. Lemongrass is delicious bargain.
author: Todd P.

description:
I probably should have taken the fact that Lemongrass was completely empty at lunch time on a Thursday afternoon into consideration before continuing with my decision to eat here on a recent vacation. 

We were promptly greeted by the hostess who showed us to our table and brought over menus and water. After a good 10-15 minutes of reviewing the menu, she sheepishly came over and gave us the lunch menu, apologizing for presenting it when we first arrived. The lunch menu made us change our initial choices, and we went with the following items:

1) Papaya Salad: I've recently developed a huge appreciation for papaya salads when dining out for Thai cuisine. The papaya was fresh and crispy and was served alongside other vegetables. The sauce was a bit sweeter than what I was used to and lacked the typical heat that comes with a properly spiced salad. It was good, but definitely not the best I've had.
2) Nuer Pad Plik was my boyfriend's choice, which was tender beef sauteed with fresh chili, basil and hot chili sauce. He commented that this dish was a bit sweet for his liking and that it didn't taste as hot as the description indicated. The meat was also chewy, leading for an overall "meh" feeling towards the entree.
3) Pad Thai with prawns: This was just... okay. The sauce was also sweet (I'm sensing a pattern here) instead of the typical peanut base. The noodles were also more spaghetti like in size which I didn't really care for. The prawns were fresh, but they had a scant representation in the dish. The serving size was large, but I didn't want to eat much of this dish. 

The service was incredibly slow and it took us about 15 minutes to get our waitress's attention once we had finished so that we could get our check and leave. I definitely wouldn't go out of my way to eat here as I'm sure there are other better Thai offerings in the area.
author: Megan K.

description:
I love coming to Lemongrass. This is the place to take friends from out of town. The staff is friendly and the food is authentic and out of this world. We had the stuffed chicken wings for starters and the spinach leaves with an incredible sauce, hand cut toasted coconut mmm. I love Pad Thia and it is done the right way here.
every time I come here I try something new and always pleasantly surprised. Thank You, Thank You!
author: Bobby M.

description:
Pros:
Delicious curries; Great wine menu; Lovely window seating; Clean restrooms; Efficient and friendly service; Affordable meals with sizeable portions; Tasteful decor.
author: Gabriel A.

description: I am officially a Lemongrass fan. I came here with a couple girlfriends on Saturday night around 9:30 and we got a table right away. The best part of the night was a couple of drunk thirty-something women who were a tad bit crazy. In terms of the food,  it was just as ridiculous, but in a good way. We had the Tom Kha Gai (coconut milk soup with chicken and mushrooms) and it was heavenly. Then we had the Pad See Ew (thick noodles) which was super yummy and the Panang Curry (good but I've had better). The atmosphere was casual and relaxed besides the floozies next to us, but the service was super friendly and great. I would highly recommend and would come back anytime I'm in the area again.
author: Shayna S.

description: Someone wrote that this is a "neighborhood gem" and I wholeheartedly agree. We have been coming here consistently for years, although we've moved and are no longer down the street from it. The food is fantastic - always really, really fresh and flavorful. We often order for delivery (easier with kids) and the food arrives quickly and piping hot. Lemongrass is also my go-to restaurant when we have folks over, because I know it's going to be great, and a real crowd-pleaser. They've never let me down. We love Lemongrass.
author: Amanda T.

description: I would give 0 stars if I could. We ordered food at the start of the Warriors game and by the 4th quarter we still were without food. We waited over 2 HOURS, they kept saying that it would be just a few more minutes.... And the food never showed up. Ended up canceling. So disappointed.
author: Sydney P.

description: It was probably the coldest night I have ever experienced in SFO. I was visiting from out of town and determined to hit up Nick's Crispy Tacos. We got to Nick's after a marathon shopping session only to discover it was Taco Tuesday and not only was it packed but it reminded me of my cheesy clubbing days that I thought I had left behind in 2001. Where to eat? Where to go? We stumbled upon this gem of a place only a couple of blocks up from Nick's. I ordered the special, Lemongrass chicken with a side of steamed rice. The portions were huge for the price and the taste better than I had anticipated. You can really taste the fresh ingredients. The service was attentive and the restaurant clean. It must be a neighbourhood favourite because at least a dozen people stopped by to pick up food in the course of our dinner. Will definitely be back and recommend to my colleagues that often visit SFO.
author: Michelle B.

description: Nothing remarkable, but nothing bad either.  Fine for when you're having a major Thai food craving and it's right in front of you.
author: Lisa F.

description: I live right by lemongrass so i've been coming here for years with my family. my mom and i always get their sticky mango rice to go to share! it's delicious and their mangoes are usually ripe. we've gotten dinner here before too and it was lovely. the place is very cozy and the waitresses are very smiley!
author: Kayla O.

description:
I'm always tempted to get one of two dishes at any Thai restaurant: yellow curry or pad thai. And I've had these two dishes at Lemongrass, and they were both great. But on my last visit, I decided to branch out with a pork-and-vegetables dish. Change is good!

This restaurant has a great menu, a few unique appetizer items, and a decent ambiance (enough idle noise for it to seem busy, but quiet enough to hold an actual conversation with the person(s) at your table). 

The one negative(?) thing I'd say about this place is that it's a bit... boring. By that, I mean that I've never been noticeably stoked to get food there. It's not a *destination*, if that makes sense. If you're looking for an awesome time enhanced by the atmosphere, this probably isn't your place. But the food and service are excellent, so it's more of a nice, simple, quiet-night-out type of restaurant.
author: Stefanie L.

description:
The service was good and the prices were low, but the food was mediocre. 

I ordered a chicken curry and requested that they make it extra spicy. It was not spicy at all. It wasn't bad, but there are many better Thai restaurants in SF.
author: Casey N.

description: Food was blend. And I've asked for spicy!!!
author: Julia J.

description:
My date and I were looking for a yummy, easy and inexpensive bite to eat on Polk Street. This is not an easy feat - especially on a busy Friday night. I had walked by Lemongrass multiple times and never tried it so, I thought, why not? I am glad I did!

The food was good - it was a nice balance of spicy, sweet, salty. I especially liked the pineapple fried rice with chunks of chicken and shrimp. I also ordered the tom yum pak soup with tofu and veggies. Beware! It is spicier than you might think.

The atmosphere is cozy and homey and the service is fast and polite. All in all, Lemongrass is a pleasant surprise on normally food-deficient Polk Street.
author: Jocelyn F.

description:
Don't let the decor fool you - this is actually a substandard to poor Thai restaurant. 

First the pros: nice Buddha statues....good service. Yup. That's about it. 

The food is very poorly made, without skill or apparent experience. The little things make all the difference - for example, raw (unfried) tofu in a panang curry? Destroys the entree. No vegetables in the panag except zucchini, which jut made the meal even more bizarre. 

The Pad See Ew was laced with sour-smelling egg and when we asked for it spicy, the chef poured pepper on the top. My roommate skipped her meal after taking a few bites. 

There are certain items that are standard/edible (hence the two stars) - I got the ground chicken with basil, which was decent. 

Finally, and most importantly, my roommates and I asked for our food spicy. We're all Indian and have high tolerances for spicy food - we all wound up sick to our stomach and I threw my leftovers away on our way out of the restaurant. 

Want Thai food? Steer clear of Lemongrass.
author: Meghana D.

description:
TOI (chef/owner) is the real deal.   Authentic Thai.  Great service.  Won "Best of the Bay 2010".  A very well deserving award. 

DON'T be deterred by reviews of those "who have traveled to Thailand" or "consider themselves knowledgeable in Thai cuisine".   (please...) 

DO have the Mieng-Kum, Appetizer plate and/or Satay, and the Chicken Savory. 

Congratulations Toi and Lemongrass! 

 Khorb Khun! Kor sa dang kuam yin dee Ka!
author: Vivian E.

description:
This place has great food. I tried the Lemongrass Chicken Savory and some other dish I can't remember...I had two Sanghi beers' which were very light.  
We had one waitress that was surprisingly unfriendly.  The other was totally friendly in her attire was beautiful.  One thing that honestly shocked me when I walked into the place was that their statue has a stack of quarters in its left palm.  The statue is of someone in meditation...maybe it is just me but I would think the focus of money would be more subtle.
author: Salonje R.

description: I have lived in this area for a long time and have eaten some really good thai food and some ok food also. This was the worse I have eaten. It was a lot of cut uncooked vegetables in a little bit of soup. The curries were watery. The rice was also kind of uncooked. The only thing that was good was the service and they get  my star for that.The ladies who served us were really nice and friendly. I just wish the food was also as good as their service.
author: R M.

description:
Dear Lemongrass,
I always enjoy dining with you. In fact, I enjoy it so much I even get take out occasionally. My problem with takeout is usually how guilty I feel about all the wasted packaging. Recently, I received takeout from you that had a bunch of plastic wrapped around the plastic container and that made me feel another level of guilty for getting takeout instead of dining at home with my own plates and silverware. Until you switch to compostable takeout, may I suggest you avoid wrapping the plastic in plastic?
author: polina S.

description:
We can make this quick:

-The atmosphere is charming and far nicer than what you'd expect at the price point (great value!).

-The food is consistently good across all categories.  Noodles: check, curries: check, mixed dishes: chuck, hot plates: check.

-Service is very polite and attentive.  

Finally I'll add this is probably the best Thai place in the vicinity.
author: David K.

description: Good neighborhood Thai food restaurant. Came here on a Friday night and the restaurant was not very crowded, but it took a while for our food to arrive. Seems to be a very popular spot for takeout food.
author: Scoot S.

description: I used to love this place but last night I ordered takeout. I asked for spring rolls, which was surprisingly confusing for them but we finally landed on what I meant. I ended up bringing home uncooked eggrolls. I am kicking myself for not checking what i had in the bag- so strange. Also the phad thai shrimp tasted like dirt. Without the shrimp it was fine but if you mess up my phad thai, I cant ever give you a second chance. Damn damn
author: S M.

description:
This place is pretty dashed good.

It is not going to win any Michelin Stars, but it certainly isn't sending people away unhappy.

The food was pretty tasty and the service was good.

The only reason I am docking them a point is after they brought us the wrong beer, it appeared as if the lady forced the bottle cap back on it.  Not sure how much I appreciated that.
author: Adam O.

description:
This place really is amazing.  Lunch menu is so good and the prices are very reasonable considering the large portions. 
Get the veggie egg rolls there great, a good lunch dish is the special savory chicken, comes out on a sizzling plate with your choice of rice! 
They have a lot of veggie dish options as well for the anti meat folk.
author: David R.

description:
comments for to-go order only

came in on a weekend night and they were busy! there were a few orders ahead of us to go, they also had delivery orders, and they have a few tables filled. definitely a good sign that the restaurant is busy! 

i tried the pad thai, pineapple friend rice, and pad see you. all delicious. you cannot go wrong. comfort food all the way and left satisfied! :)
author: Jen S.

description:
Pretty Good Thai food - some of the best on polk st.

Good ambiance, and very reasonable prices. Consistently good food makes this a good "first date" place? "Why first date," you might ask, skeptically? Because:

1) You know you're going to get a good meal out of it, so you'll be stuffing your face instead of having to come up with awkward things to say
2) its pretty inexpensive, but you can get away with it because thai food is still considered "exotic" enough for you to let her know "hey, im adventurous!" or "I like to have a good time!"
3) It seems clean and well run, which is an absolute requirement for any first date - i don't care how adventurous you want to be. Grossed out girl is not a good thing for you. 
4) If the date turns out to be absolute crap, you don't have to feel like an idiot the next day for spending 90 bucks on a girl you didn't even like.

Recommend: everything's pretty good here, but the curries are notable, and my friends really like their pumpkin curry. I prefer the pad kee mow (drunken noodles), just cause i love me some noodles.

small complaint: I wish they'd give me more noodles and less of the stuff on top. This is especially true for the pad thai. If you go and order this, I'd ask for more noodles with your dish or something.
author: James W.

description:
pad makuer tofu - eggplant with tofu, garlic, green/red peppers, chili, basil

this dish is AMAZING. very garlicy, but worth every bite.

it usually goes like this in my head:

"i'm hungry, what should I make?"
"i'm too lazy to make something, i want thai food"
call lemongrass - order pad makuer tofu without fish sauce (it's vegan)
15 minutes, pick up food and take it home
"ok, i'm only going to eat half"
put half on a plate, put the other half in the fridge
eat the food on my plate
"hmmm, i want some more"
go to fridge and start eating more out of the container...it always ends in finishing the entire thing!

the tom yum pak soup is pretty good too, it's also huge and i always end up eating the entire thing. the other dishes i've had were nothing memorable, but i give lemongrass 5 stars for the pad makuer tofu, it's just that good.

i've only gotten take-out, so not sure how the service is but they are friendly.
author: Elaine S.

description: First time here. Hands down...best meal at a restaurant ever. Crispy Rice Salad, Lemongrass Chicken and Tofu with Crispy Basil. The place is small and got crowded as the evening went on. Good service, friendly and attentive wait staff. $60 included one other app, the above mentioned dishes and two teas. Well worth it. My only complaint? It is in SF and not my home town!
author: Jennifer B.

description: Not a fan.  Ordered takeout with my girl -- got the green curry (with beef), yellow curry (with chicken), and pad see-uw (with pork).  I always order pad see-uw as a control when I visit a new thai restaurant.  This order tasted strangely sweet and was just off overall.  The curries were pretty good, but did NOT sit well.  Stomach still hurting.  Take your money elsewhere... I liked T2J down the street more.
author: Jonathan S.

description:
I always like the food here more than I thought I would.  I've eaten here at least 3 times now, and i'm always pleasantly re-surprised.  Nice, candle lit, warm, casual environment with cozy thai atmosphere.  (and great prices.)

Got carryout this last time and they forgot to pack the rice, though!  oops.  Luckily, it turned out even better than expected when we added our own rice noodles that we unusually had sitting around in a cupboard at home.  The dishes didn't look so exciting at first when we opened up the styrofoam coffins they came in, but it was all really fresh tasting, cooked just right, and very flavorful with natural, clean, zesty flavors.  Even the boring looking sauteed spinach was really addicting and satisfying.  Felt kinda healthy, wholesome and not boring at all.

Mango rice dessert was SCRUMPTIOUS!
author: Today Y.

description:
For $60 (inc. tip), we got: 

3 glasses of Beringer 
1 order of Chicken Satay 
1 order of Lemon Chicken 
1 Tom Yum Gai Soup 

Not a bad deal, but not a great one. The food was pretty tasty & full of flavor. Another plus is the attentive service. 

A solid 3-star in my book.
author: Heidi B.

description: I usually go for lunch and always start out with a cup of the Tom Kha Gai soup...soo good. Their Gai Gra Tiem and Pad Thai are great too. They also deliver!
author: Daniel K.

description: This is the best Thai food I've had in San Francisco. The service is always friendly and quick and they deliver. I recommend the pineapple fried rice, tom yum gai, and the spicy calamari.
author: Alyssa L.

description:
Unimpressive thai on the expensive side. I yelped for a Thai place in Russian Hill and this came up. I thought, okay, sure, why not. Got some pad kee mao for myself and some pad see ew for my boyfriend.  Noodles got kind of soggy in a to-go box. 

Maybe it would have been better if we ate it there? But no - thai food needs to travel well and Lemongrass didn't make the cut. Next time we'll try the thai in fisherman's wharf (Mood Thai Sushi, I believe it's called) which I was hesitant to try at first because it's fisherman's wharf and by default I question the quality of everything in the radius, but it just might be a better bet. 

Or I'll just drive an extra five mins to Osha. I'd much rather do that than waste $20 on bad thai!
author: Shannon R.

description: Take out was okay, but not that great.  More soon.
author: Kelly K.

description:
Went here on a Monday night with a friend after doing a Yelp search for Thai food in the area. The place seemed much more fancy/date-ish than I was expecting, based on the prices I had seen online. Nothing bad, just unexpected! My friend had the Sweet and Sour Chicken, and I had the Spicy Tofu. Both were ok, nothing to rave about. Decently priced though, and the waitress was very nice. However, the one thing that irks me is that you have to pay extra for rice. I understand having to pay extra for rice if you ordered a noodle dish, but for curries and other saucey dishes??? 

All in all, I don't necessarily plan on going back myself, but if my friends wanted to go, I would tag along.
author: Kimberly K.

description:
tasteless food and unfriendly service. 

They also tried to tell us the credit card machine was broken. When we had no cash, the card machine miraculously started working again. I just wish they had been honest; we wouldn't have minded running to the ATM if they had just been upfront!
author: Cece L.

description:
New Year's Day; National Hangover Day; NO ONE wants to cook. Fair enough.

For me, showering wasn't even on the agenda... so eating "out" wasn't really happening.  With a hungover hankering for some tasty Thai, I call Lemongrass.

"Hello- you hold on?!... click".... I call back. (desperate for Thai food).

"Hello- you hold on just one minue?" I reply "sure- ok."

About 4 minutes later: "Ok- what you lie?"

I go through my order, then she says "How many people this for?" I say, "Two."

She asks "Where  you live?"

I say "Presidio" then give my address. 

She says "Oh, we too busy deliver  presidio- you not 'nough people." (Even though my total doubles the delivery minimum.)

Desperate.... I agree to pick up my food.

Good food, no apology from them for the inconvenience though.

I'll just have to remember to "have 'nough people" next time I want delivery.
author: Kaitlyn G.

description: I been coming here for almost ten year and its my favorite. I felt it was time I Yelp about it. The food is authentic , good price and services. It is more that you get for the value - casual yet comfortable and elegant. Over the years I have gotten to speak to the owner and she is just  sweet and still very vested in her business. Love this place.
author: Teddy T.

description: Here's the short version: the Tom Yum Gai was tasty, the green curry was good, but the poached trout special was poor: the trout was fishy, the sauce was way too sweet, and the broccoli was cold. Service was good. I won't be rushing back.
author: Kurt A.

description:
Eh, this place was ok.  We ordered delivery one saturday evening because we decided on dinner and a movie to relax a little bit.  Delivery took about 45 minutes which was fine and the food was nice and hot when we got it.  I was a little annoyed because I specifically asked if the dishes came with rice and the lady on the phone said one came with rice and one didn't so i asked to order an EXTRA rice.  when the food came, we only get the extra rice i ordered and not the one that actually came with the dish.

the flavors were good, but not amazing and the food was kind of greasy.  pretty cheap thai food, though, so i would probably give it another try before writing it off complete.y
author: Lisa C.

description: Very good food - tom yang gung, satay, Red curry with shrimp and Pad Thai.  Good service as well.
author: John R.

description: A little pricey for take out (about $8 - 9 an entree) but solid Thai cuisine.  Clean and comfortable dining room and very pleasant wait staff.
author: K P.

description:
I am so happy to be living in a neighborhood that has this awesome gemstone of a restaurant right down the street from my home.  Whether it is delivery or dine-in, I have always been pleased and we've become regulars.  

My standards for Thai food are incredibly high - I've vacationed in Thailand before and I spent 9 days eating as much authentic Thai cuisine as I could.

When ordering for delivery they have always been quick, polite, and easy to work with.  Notable menu choices include their egg rolls, satay (looooooooove the peanut sauce, you can usually find me slurping up the remaining last drops out of the little cups they provide), beef with spinach, and the classic pad Thai is divine.  Their coconut milk soup is fantastic, and their pineapple fried rice brings me back to the beaches of Pattaya, chowing down on splendid deliciousness in a nameless hole in the wall. 

The dine-in experience is not too bad.  While the restaurant is small and the tables are tight, the decor is nice and they try to pay attention to details.  The window seats are by far the most attractive, but overall the place is clean and tidy.  It's usually pretty empty in the early evenings and on weekdays...but since it's so convenient to get it delivered to us, we don't normally eat in.

Lemongrass is cheap and their portions are big.  If you're starving, polish the meal off, but usually we have wonderful, stomach-pleasing leftovers.  There's enough authenticity and flavor in their meals for you to easily forget yourself and stuff your face.  We've recommended the place to multiple friends and they all agree - Lemongrass is gooood.
author: Marie B.

description:
When people ask me where the best Thai restaurant is in SF, I immediately say Lemongrass without a doubt.  I've never had a bad dish here, it is definitely authentic Thai!  

Toi Sawatdee, the owner and chef, is one of the nicest people I've ever met.  It is not uncommon to see her personally greeting the customers or even taking your order. 

Lemongrass will also cater events and doesn't hesitate to make sure that it provides the best food/service possible!
author: Pam G.

description: Both classic and somewhat classy Thai restaurant look. The service and food were fine for the price. My pad-see-ew had the right spicy kick and basil-y sweetness and might even have been good enough to write home about ... If it weren't for the mushy tofu. Please, Lemongrass, fry your tofu and ascend to the next level of vegetarian awesomeness.
author: Daniel Levis K.

description:
We ordered delivery from Lemongrass on Sunday afternoon, while in the mood for a little Thai. We ordered the shrimp pad thai and the papaya salad. 

Both were overpriced and terrible. When I say terrible, I mean "I am totally starving, but still won't eat this food" terrible. 

I have eaten here a few times in the past and I remembered it to be solid, so I was completely disappointed.
author: Daniel S.

description:
We have ordered from Lemongrass twice. Overall,  pretty tasty food, large portions, and VERY quick delivery. The only complaint I have is that the Pad Thai wasn't very flavorful....but maybe they were having an off-day. 
The curry we ordered was delicious, and you MUST try the Mieng-Kum appetizer, ABSOLUTELY DELISH!
author: adrienne l.

description: When I want red curry with beef or green curry with chicken, this is where I order from.  Yes - they deliver.
author: Tapedeck B.

description:
Great Thai food, great charm. Favorite Thai restaurant in the city. 

Only gripe is that they are stingy with spoons. You aren't supposed to eat Thai food with a fork...
author: Patrick K.

description:
A great find in the Russian Hill district! I had a friend in town and decided to take him around SF and we ended up here. I'm glad we stumbled upon this place because the food here was great! It wasn't too salty or oily like many Thai places tend to be.

The service was nice and they were very attentive to our water and served us rice. The atmosphere here is comfortable. The food wasn't too spicy. The sliced beef dish's lime sauce had a strong kick to it. The rahnah was excellent. I wasn't crazy about the wine selection here. The fried banana with ice cream was a perfect way to end the meal.
author: Melissa T.

description: My favorite Thai place in SF.  Very extensive menu.   The Lemongrass Chicken Savory is my go-to dish!   The pad-thai is also great.  Not too sweet.   Food preparation is quick and service very friendly.
author: Goli M.

description:
I have only dined at Lemongrass once, and hope to get back there soon!

As the reviews have said, the food was delicious and their service was nothing below excellent.
author: claire s.

description:
I've only tried this place for lunch and so far have only ordered the personal lunch kind of dish so I can't really comment on how authentic or how great their dinner selection is.
I've had Pad Thai (which was only okay), beef/chicken/pork with sweet basil sauce served with rice (which was excellent). My coworkers ordered a few other lunch dishes (some curry chicken noodles) and they liked it.
author: Anh V.

description: There was a foot-long hair in my pad-thai, they delivered my food without any utensils, and the spring rolls were not tasty. I threw everything away.
author: Marianne G.

description: The service here is still exceptional, both when ordering for delivery and dining in, but the food has recently started lacking in flavor.  We would always order yellow curry with chicken and the spicy basil eggplant with tofu and it was always delicious.  Not saying it is not good now, it just doesn't taste as good.  Please go back to your old techniques and ways of cooking so I would be motivated to order from you again when I am in the Bay Area for business.  I miss your food and service the way it used to be.
author: Steve C.

description: This is not a 3.5 star quality restaurant. It's below average, over priced, tiny yet well kept place.  I m thai food lover and the food here wasn't tasty or flavorful at all. I order vegetarian red curry with pineapple. The waitress told me it would be $2 for adding pineapple (which I was ok with) and they also charged for rice (first time I ever paid for rice at a thai place). Waitress didn't ask me spice level at this point. When the food came it was mild & flavor less red curry with tofu (i never asked to add tofu) + pineapple.  Also, i bit into either a small stone or shell which was in my curry.
author: H P.

description:
This whole weekend I was super lucky to find really good food.  Lemongrass was also right on the mark of amazing.  I've had a lot of Thai food, and I've been sad I really haven't found THE place I'd goto for good Thai.  This might be it.

Everything was fantastic, tasty, but not salty nor too heavy.  My glass of water was always full!

Charming place, great neighborhood, and the food was awesome.  I'll definitely come here again.
author: Art C.

description:
I don't recommend this restaurant! Sadly, this was the worst Thai food I've had. The ambiance is cute and the waitresses were very, very polite, nice, and friendly. But the food was sub-par! 

My friends and I went there for dinner tonight and ordered 5 entrees. We weren't a fan of 4 out of the 5 entrees (we ordered some sort of curry, sizzling chicken mushroom dish, beef pad thai, and sauteed beef dish). And the 5th dish (the thai basil) was mediocre / average.

The pad thai had a VERY strange hoisin-sauce taste to it, the beef in the sauteed dish seemed to be low quality, chewy meat although the flavor was relatively tasty, the sizzling chicken mushroom dish looked promising but ended up tasting too garlicky and heavily seasoned, and the curry was below average in terms of overall taste and texture.

We all agreed that we wouldn't be coming back, and we didn't even come close to finishing our food because none of us were into most of the dishes.

If you're looking for a Thai place near here, check out Modern Thai in Nob Hill instead - they have amazing coconut green curry, pad thai, and thai basil!!
author: Amy D.

description: I'd prefer the frozen Pad Thai from Trader Joe's than what they serve here.  Sorry!
author: Robby W.

description:
I got off work late last night and decided I want Thai. So, one of my staff members and myself read great reviews for this place. We called in our order so it would be ready when we arrived. I had the chicken pad see ew. She had the tofu red curry. Food was good. It did remind me of mom's homecooking, which I don't get often.

The only thing that really bothered me was our waitress. Perhaps she was having a bad night?? When she asked us if we liked anything else besides water to drink, we were trying to look at the drink list, but she snatched it up! I'm not sure what that was all about. So we just stuck with water. Honestly, every time she came by our table we felt like we were bugging her. There were 2 other tables but not crazy busy.

Because of our experience with the waitress, we're not going back. I'm sure we can get Thai somewhere else with better customer service. Seems like we were the only ones who had to deal with this
author: Lola D.

description: Seriously? how is this place even in business still with all the far superior/tastier thai restaurants in the city. How can you mess up pad thai --- this place did. Will never eat here again! Go to Yukol Thai on Lombard instead! it's WAYYYY better.
author: Shivani S.

description:
Discovered this gem of a place from a yelp search and very glad that i did. A snug, cool little restaurant with a warm feel and an even warmer service. The food was spot on too. 
The Thai green curry and the, ever popular, pad Thai was scrumptious. Very authentic and did i say scrumptious already? 

my wife and i can't wait to get back to try the pumpkin shrimp curry.
author: ali n.

description: I was in the area getting my hair colored at the tulip salon.  I decided to stop by.  I love their pineapple fried rice.  It has a great flavor.  I have had pineapple rice in several different Thai restaurants, so i was expecting it to have cashews which it was missing.  Other than that it was great.  The waitress was very nice and delivered my meal right away.  Great service and good food. =)
author: Maria N.

description:
When we first walked in (a group of 4 girls, former roommates, catching up after about 6 mos apart) we realized we might be a bit too loud for the place. However, we weren't drinking (it was 6 pm!), so once we got used to the quiet, romantic/biz-dinner mood, all was well. The decor was very nice, the seating comfortable.. a very classy looking place.

With great prices, very tasty food-- why haven't I been here before? We got:

--Some kind of spicy soup... apparently it was delicious, but I didn't try it. Serving was ginormous for the price.
--Green Curry Salmon Special... quite yummy. The fish was fresh, the curry was spot on. More than enough for one person to take some home for leftovers.
--Yellow Curry (this was mine)... About what you expect; sweet, but not too sweet. Veggies were about standard.
... and some other soup I didn't try. So I'm not a soup fan! My friends are, and they liked this place.

Overall: 3.5 for the food, 4 for the decor, 4 for value of quantity&quality/price.
author: Samantha B.

description: This restaurant reminds me of the Thai places that I would frequent in college. It's fairly quick, has large portions, and the price is very reasonable. The red curry and pineapple fried rice are both really satisfying and filling. The pad see ew is okay, but the noodles were a little clumped together the time I went. The restaurant itself is kind of cramped. I could definitely hear the conversations of the people on both sides of our table, and I'd have to scoot my chair in every time someone wanted to pass behind me. Nevertheless, the food here is definitely worth trying.
author: Jessica W.

description: Wow, this place was fully packed on a Wednesday at 8pm. The decor is very nice and dimly lit, perfect for a date place. The wait staff is very attentive and profession. My friend had the Lemongrass Chicken skillet which came out piping hot while I had the Pad See Yoo. The Pad See Yoo was OK. Nothing exciting. Not the best I've tasted. The Chicken dish looked a lot better. The sauce it came in was very good (didn't have the chicken because I don't eat meat). Service is fast and 2 dishes were $30 including tip. Kinda expensive.
author: Katie Anne N.

description: Lemongrass has the BEST pineapple fried rice and their pad thai jay is delish too!
author: Liz Y.

description:
After a looooonnngg day of cheerleading, sometimes you need a good hearty meal...

Complete with yellow chicken curry, and loads of rice!

Cuz you know this Asian loves his rice.


Our meal was SUPER cheap, especially since I had been relying on the close by Osha for a good thai plate.  But lemongrass has stolen my heart.

My fellow cheermate ordered the green vegetable curry, which was also a delectable bite.

I will so be back, it's not even funny.
author: Vince S.

description:
Ok Thai food, decent prices, good service. I like the big plants and the traditional decor.

I'm not very excited or passionate about this place however, and though I work nearby, I've only eaten here a few times, I don't really know why...

Most people I know in the neighborhood love Lemongrass...its a good neighborhood place.
author: Nilu r.

description:
Lemongrass chicken savory.  'Nough said.

It's like a Thai fajita.../ Thai food facial-- a must experience


Sooooooooooooo good

(Also great is the Tofu Basil- note: both of these items are off the "specials" menu)
author: Gabrielle J.

description:
Lemongrass "special: noodle was gross and found plastic in it.

Papaya salad was ok but too much vinegar

Smells so good after I work out @ Crunch but so far, food sucked
author: Peter K.

description: This has been our go to favorite Thai in the city for decades. Last two times it's been just terrible. Tonight we had the green curry, pad see Yu and veggie egg rolls. Everything was flavorless at best. In fact neither of us could even finish our plate much less get seconds. Terribly disappointing.
author: Courtney M.

description:
I live right near Lemongrass, so I get takeout pretty often.

I'm a curry-guy at heart, and Lemongrass doesn't disappoint on this front. Like all places in the city, you've got to order your own rice to go with it (who made that rule, by the way?). The yellow curry is my favorite.

Other dishes are:
Deep fried tofu (mmm)
Pad Makuer Tofu (possibly the best vegetarian dish I have ever had)


I would stay away from the pad thai -- it isn't bad, but there are a million places that do it better. If you're really craving a noodle dish, get the Pad See-Ew or the Pad Kemow
author: Max F.

description: For being a Thai restaurant on one of the most popular streets in SF you would think it would be good or at least decent! I didn't know pad Thai could be bad, or chicken skewers. Save you're time and money. There are much better restraints in the city
author: Jen S.

description:
Eggplant tofu is a great dish here. The rest of the stuff at my table was good-but-not-great Thai fare.

Interior 3-star, service 3-star. Prices are fair.

If you're in the neighborhood, it's a good choice for Thai, but I'd head to Thai House Express if given the chance.
author: Brian B.

description: Typical Thai restaurant with a few dozen unsubstantiated awards on the door. But this is all common of Thai restaurants, so I play along. I ordered the lunch special with yellow curry and chicken satay. The waitress brings out a salad that is almost laughable. I counted 8 pieces of iceberg lettuce with a thin and sour dressing. It was strange. However...the chicken satay w/ peanut sauce was fantastic. The BEST satay I have ever had. It had layers of flavor and the peanut sauce brought some heat. The yellow curry was perfect -- tasty with a velvet-like texture. Tip: order exactly what I did, dump the curry and peanut sauce on your rice, and use the satay skewer as your fork. Good eats.
author: Alex B.

description:
Yummy!

The food was priced well and tasted very good. I loved the decor and will definately be going back.
author: Daniella V.

description:
Here's the Cliff Notes version:

Order the Tom Yum Gai soup and Lemongrass Savory Chicken Special

Tom Yum Gai: simple, healthy, flavorful soup consisting of chicken, mushrooms and lemon grass root...the flavor of the broth is AMAZING...a bit spicy too
Lemongrass Savory Chicken: delicious, great spices, nice creamy curry sauce...trust me it's the best thing on the menu

PROS:
-Adorable, cozy, casual Thai restaurant. 
-Usually no wait.
-You can place delivery orders online

CONS:
-Delivery takes a long time. Expect to wait 45 min - 1 hour
-Most dishes are lackluster
author: Betty Y.

description:
Everything here was either really good (5 stars) or average (3), which is why I give it 4 stars. Just fyi, nothing was bad. 

The 5 star items we ordered:
- Pad Makuer Tofu: Probably the best thing we had here. Sauteed eggplant, tofu, onions, thai basil.  It had a very strong thai basil flavor that permeated the entire dish. Yum yum! The thai basil was so fully soaked in all the tofu and vegetables (and not just when you actually ate the basil like some other restaurants) that when I served myself some of this dish onto my pad thai, the surrounding few bites of pad thai tasted like basil. Amazing.

- Veggie egg rolls: soo yummy! They were very crispy, and the vegetables inside were very fresh, especially the mung bean sprouts, which I love. There were 6 pieces (3 long egg rolls cut diagonally),

- Papaya salad. I always love papaya salad, but this one was exceptionally good. It had a really fresh, vinegary/lemon taste and it was just the perfect level of spiciness. (We didn't blow steam and sweat buckets like we did across the street at the Vietnamese place Aux Delices-- thought that was also good)

- Red curry with mixed veg: Solid curry. Good amount of curry, and I liked the proportion of curry to vegetables (last thai place I went to had 80% vegetables and 20% actual curry! boo!) The best thing we had here was the pad makuer tofu--- Sauteed eggplant and tofu with garlic chili sauce and basil.  Very strong thai basil flavor! Yum yum! It was fully soaked in all the tofu and vegetables, not just when you actually ate the basil. Ours had a slight bite, but it wasn't spicy-- I'm sure you could ask for it spicier.

3 star items (good but average):
- Poh-pier-sod: This was a rice paper roll stuffed with tofu, cucumber, carrots, etc. It was good, but I probably won't order it again. Easy appetizer to share-- came with 8 pieces. 

- Pad thai: This was good, but I've definitely had better. 
It didn't have the strong fish sauce flavor that some Thai restaurants have. Some people prefer that strong flavor, some people hate that-- all depends. Just your average pad thai, really. It didn't dance for me. 


General note:
Pretty big portions though!
Nice "authentic" (*disclaimer: never been to Thailand) decor.
author: Saori E.

description:
Everything my former Seattle go-to thai joint was: typical warm thai ambience and service if not a little upscale, consistently good on the basics (phad thai, pad see ew) and reasonable prices ($8.71 for pad see ew after tax). And unlike so many thai places I've tried in the bay area, Lemongrass really does understand my thirst for thai-level spice. 

Easy on the adjectives though, because they seemingly have no limits. My last dish to go was labeled "very very spicy" as that's exactly what I asked for, and the spice level was near suicidal. I appreciate them catering to my literal request though. I'll just say "spicy" next time. Only reason this place doesn't get five stars is b/c I haven't really sampled too much of their menu...it's been more of a to-go spot for me, but the space is definitely nice for eating in.
author: Brian N.

description: This place is a total RIP OFF. I got an entree with shrimp and vegetables. It came with carrots and 3 shrimp. Not even enough for two people. Total rip off. Super expensive too.
author: Anne Marie R.

description: This place was pretty good. I came here with a friend last week as a random Polk Street dinner option after passing by on a Friday evening. It was pretty busy inside, but not too busy to get a table for 2 right away. We ordered a bottle of wine, a steak dish, and a chicken and thai basil dish with veggies. The food was pretty good. Portions are huge, and prices are decent for what you get. I believe my dish was $9 for the chicken and thai basil. Service was standard, nothing out of the ordinary. I'd come back here again for a casual meal out with a friend or two.
author: Ashley D.

description:
I've been meaning to write an update on this place and just never got around to it.  I came here about 6 months ago and haven't been back....and I'm not sure I will.  I used to think this place was great but maybe I had just ordered the right things or maybe they have just gone downhill.  Either way, with so many good places to eat in this city, I'm not going to waste my money here.  The last time I came in for lunch the service was awful and rude and the meal was mediocre at best.  I asked if I could order a cup of the Tom Kha because it wasn't on the menu.  The waitress said "yes, but you're going to order more than that, right??" I told her that I was planning on it and then wondered whether I looked particularly thin or shabby that day. Trying to put that out of my mind, I continued browsing the menu trying to find something different.  I usually order a curry so i decided to go with something I hadn't tried before (and maybe this was my mistake) and ordered some fried tofu dish with crispy basil.  The sauce was bland, the tofu was chewy and again...bland, and the basil was just weird.  The problem with tofu is that generally it is pretty flavorless but it soaks up whatever sauce you cook it in.  So if the sauce is bland, the tofu is bland.  I would expect a Thai restaurant to understand this.  On top of it all the waitress continued to be short with me.  I used to order take out form here very frequently and came in for dinner every so often.  I doubt I will be back (especially with Aux Delices right across the street).  I don't understand how they are voted "Best Thai" over and over.  Wait...no actually I do because those awards are all politics.


If this is your first time eating Thai food, come here and well, you might be satisfied.
author: Devin W.

description: Not only does Toi Sawatdee make the best Thai food in SF, but she's probably the nicest person I've ever met.  Lemongrass is the best deal on catering in the city (and the only Thai restaurant I could find that will fully cater your event).  Most importantly, the owner of this place (Toi) cooks here nightly so the food is always excellent.
author: Mat G.

description: Delicious Thai food!!  The service is really good and everyone is by nice.  The prices are affordable and they have a good wine selection.  I would highly recommend this restaurant to any of my friends.  They also deliver which is very convenient.
author: Stacey M.

description:
I came to town about five years ago after moving from the east coast and knowing very little about any sort of asian food.

Actually I knew more than my friends having travelled to China and Japan after moving to SF .
What I've learned about Chinese, Vietnamese, Indian, Maylasian and Thai would make my friends back home in Chi Town speachless and respect me almost as much as the Mayor .
Our Mayor Daley.

I remember his dad on TV when I was a tiny little Katherine. I had such a crush but it could never be...

I'm so artistic and creative and he is so strong and powerful ...
In terms of business and doing all that is mayorlike and to keep Chicago running like a top.( Old saying look it up ) well he doesn't have the time for such silly fantasies as my own but....

As for Mayor Daley Jr., well maybe in our next life...
He'll be more romantic and I'll become much more serious,
And we can both come back really thin too !

Oh and the food at Lemongrass, Scrumptious 
Anything with salmon, veges and coconut sauce is amazing.
In fact just tell them what you want and they will practically customize it for you if they have it.

And they deliver to the Embarcaderro. Perfect
author: Katherine N.

description:
Lemongrass is my favorite Thai in the city.

I was referred there a year or so ago by a former co-worker who's grasp on sanity is pretty tenuous - which is why I was surprised when Lemongrass turned out to be excellent!

The food is excellent w/a broad assortment of Chef's Specials and stand-by Thai favorites (can we say, Tom Kha Gai?)  All reasonably priced and carefully prepared.  Yum AND yum!

I have recently discovered that they deliver - SWANK!
author: Kate R.

description:
It's one of the better, if not the best, Thai in Russian Hill.  A step up from the more casual Thai joints, the ambiance is just right for dining in.  The Basil Tofu was excellent:  perfectly crisp on the outside, while retaining a firm texture inside, not soggy in the least.  All wearing matching outfits, the wait staff is friendly and accomodating.

Downsides:  Can get crowded on the weekend (make reservations to be on the safe side), and parking.
author: Marsha Z.

description:
Late night take out is the best!

I love their pumpkin curry; it's great.  & pretty much everything I've had here has been great.

The ambiance is good, & they deliver to the Russian Hill area.

:O)
author: Minju A.

description:
I was never excited about Thai Cuisine until I came across Lemongrass. 

It was a rainy Monday night with few people spending their evening out on the town. We wanted something fresh new and somewhat healthy. We have tried most places in Russian Hill and Nob Hill, but little did we know how Lemongrass would spark a new love for Thai food.

I was pleasantly surprised by the soft, warm, inviting ambiance and the friendly staff. We were lucky enough to utilize one of their reserved parking spots in front. Once we got settled inside we were greeted by the most friendly petite Thai woman. She was an enjoyable waitress and recommended the best dishes to try. 

We started out with a spicy soup with shrimp and moved on to a tofu dish and the other a chicken dish on the specials. Each item had a unique delicious flavor. 

I am very exited to find a new favorite place just right around the corner. With reasonable prices for an amazing dinner. 

I recommend to enjoying a cup of Jasmine tea as well...

Cheers!
author: Dee C.

description:
I think I am just got tired of Thai thing. 
it was really cool and IN in 90's, those Thai curry, What do you say? sounds like a..... Gan Gari gai or something? 
their chicken satay was dry.
And, I don't even order Pad Thai anymore. Pad Thai makes me like a dog having peanut butter.
I think I am over it. 
I think Burma, Indian, Pho and Ramen took over these days.
author: Nobu K.

description:
I rarely order delivery. In fact, whenever I do, I regret not saving a menu from where ever I last ordered because I can never remember. Thanks to Yelp, I had bookmarked this place to review from February! Yes, that's how long it was since I had last ordered delivery.

As far as I can remember I don't think they even took the 45 mins they said they'd be- maybe 30? I live pretty close to the place though...

On to the food...

Tom Kha Ga Soup- delicious and a large 32oz portion that you can definitely enjoy for a couple of days or share with a few people.

Pad Thai- standard but good. The noodles were a little sticky I think...flavor was good and amount of tofu, shrimp, chopped peanuts and sprouts was perfect. Just a bit sticky...

Chicken Satay- tasty, well prepared, but I wish there were maybe 2 more skewers (I think there were 4).

I'll definitely order again. This is my go-to delivery place :)
author: Diane S.

description:
Mmmmm so delicious.  I've been here a couple of times and never had a bad entree.  Plus the service is fast and friendly.

This is a good place to bring a group of friends to or to just hang out and have tea while you read a book.  The atmosphere is casual and really welcoming.
author: Gloria J.

description:
I have recently become a self-proclaimed connoisseur of papaya salad.  Ever since my fiance force fed it to me a few months back I have been hooked.  I have to say Lemongrass has quite a tasty papaya salad.  I have probably had better papaya/whatever the other ingredients in it are at other places, but the dressing they use here is simply the bomb.  

The ladies that work here are also super sweet and attentive.  They were very friendly from the moment I walked in the door.  I also had one of the soups (I can't remember name off the top of my head) that had mushrooms, chicken and a reddish clear broth (not the coconut one) that was phenominal.  I sucked it down in about 2.5 seconds.  The green curry was also good, not the best I've had but I would definitely not judge this place poorly based on it.  

Luckily I live down the street from this place so I will definitely be back whenever I'm craving some Thai.  I would definitely choose it over the other Thai places near it on Polk. It's also near the almighty Loving Cup....phenom!
author: Mary M.

description:
I'll admit it - I'm obsessed. Addicted, in fact. Because I've never once - NOT EVEN ONE SINGLE TIME - been disappointed in my meal here.

Sigh. I'm making myself hungry already.
